page.title: 07EAST MEON - CHURCH
page.content: All Saints Church in East Meon is at the foot of Park Hill,at the junction of the 2 roads through the village. Built of local flint & with stone dressed corners,the church was at one time an important one,possibly being a Mother Church to others in the area. The present building of All Saints Church dates back to 1069,although there is some evidence that there was a wooden church building on the same site in Saxon times.Its hilly site raised above the level of the rest of the village suggests the continuance of a pagan site.Features to note include the stained glass windows,the organ,two fonts and several memorial tablets.The building has been added to over the centuries,including a new lead roof in 1985.Sheep often graze in the churchyard,which is famous for its springtime display of daffodils.
